references: In Table 3, we list attributes from the ACS and AFST data that we use for our experiments. We obtained the raw data from the IPUMS USA database [ruggles2021ipums]. The AFST data is confidential, and so access to the raw data currently requires signing a data agreement. We obtained permission from the Allegheny County Office of Children, Youth and Families to publish error plots on experiments run on a sample derived from this data. More information about the attributes used for the tool can be found in vaithianathan2017developing.

For example, given the group-level attribute Urban/rural and individual-level attributes Sex and Race, we have queries of the following form:666i.e., linear queries where ϕ​(x)=ϕ[Urban/rural = URBAN]​(x)×ϕ[Sex = FEMALE]​(x)×ϕ[Race = WHITE]​(x)italic-ϕ𝑥subscriptitalic-ϕdelimited-[]Urban/rural = URBAN𝑥subscriptitalic-ϕdelimited-[]Sex = FEMALE𝑥subscriptitalic-ϕdelimited-[]Race = WHITE𝑥\phi(x)=\phi_{[\textsc{Urban/rural = URBAN}]}(x)\times\phi_{[\textsc{Sex = FEMALE}]}(x)\times\phi_{[\textsc{Race = WHITE}]}(x).

Differentiable query answers.
An advantage of this representation is that mean aggregate queries can be calculated using basic operations over the probabilities for each attribute 𝒢isubscript𝒢𝑖{\mathcal{G}}_{i} or ℐjsubscriptℐ𝑗{\mathcal{I}}_{j}. Therefore, this formulation makes constructing differentiable functions for each predicate in Table 1 convenient. For example, to calculate that the likelihood P​[ℐSex,j=Male]𝑃delimited-[]subscriptℐSex𝑗MaleP\left[{\mathcal{I}}_{\textsc{Sex},j}=\textsc{Male}\right] that an individual generated from Pℐ,jsubscript𝑃ℐ𝑗P_{{\mathcal{I}},j} is male, one can simply look up the probability in the 222-dimensional vector corresponding to the attribute ℐj=Sexsubscriptℐ𝑗Sex{\mathcal{I}}_{j}=\textsc{Sex}. Similarly, to calculate if there is at least one male, it suffices to calculate the probability that a group (given some size m𝑚m) has no males: 1−∏j=1m(1−P​[ℐSex,j=Male])1superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑗1𝑚1𝑃delimited-[]subscriptℐSex𝑗Male1-\prod_{j=1}^{m}\left(1-P\left[{\mathcal{I}}_{\textsc{Sex},j}=\textsc{Male}\right]\right).

where for query q𝑞q, there exists a differentiable function fqsubscript𝑓𝑞f_{q} that maps from 𝐏𝒢superscript𝐏𝒢\mathbf{P}^{{\mathcal{G}}}, 𝐏ℐisuperscript𝐏subscriptℐ𝑖\mathbf{P}^{{\mathcal{I}}_{i}}, and 𝐏#superscript𝐏#\mathbf{P}^{\textrm{\#}} to the corresponding query answer. Referring to the query types in Table 1, we have that

Table 1 summarizes a general class of group and individual-level queries that are applicable to any hierarchical dataset belonging to 𝒳𝒳{\mathcal{X}}. However, we note that this list is non-exhaustive because of the innumerable ways in which one can ask queries about the composition of each group. Therefore, while we contend that the sets 𝒬Gsubscript𝒬𝐺{\mathcal{Q}}_{G} and 𝒬Isubscript𝒬𝐼{\mathcal{Q}}_{I} serve as a good basis for capturing group and individual-level relationships, there could exist additional queries that are important to specific datasets or problem domains. In particular, one interesting set of statistics that may be useful to measure are those that capture relationships between individuals belonging to the same group. For example, one common analysis employed by social scientists using the ACS involves uncovering statistical trends within spousal relationships with respect to attributes like education and ethnicity.

Combined with the predicates found in Table 1, we can construct intra-group-relationship queries 𝒬Rsubscript𝒬𝑅{\mathcal{Q}}_{R}. Suppose we have some set SGsubscript𝑆𝐺S_{G} of group-level attributes and sets SIsubscript𝑆𝐼S_{I} and SI,r​e​lsubscript𝑆𝐼𝑟𝑒𝑙S_{I,rel} of individual-level attributes (where SI,r​e​l≠∅subscript𝑆𝐼𝑟𝑒𝑙S_{I,rel}\neq\emptyset). Like in Section 3 we form singleton predicates from SGsubscript𝑆𝐺S_{G} and SIsubscript𝑆𝐼S_{I} (Table 1). However, in this case, we also add intra-group-relationship predicates formed from attributes in SI,r​e​lsubscript𝑆𝐼𝑟𝑒𝑙S_{I,rel}. For example, letting SG={Urban/rural}subscript𝑆𝐺Urban/ruralS_{G}=\left\{\textsc{Urban/rural}\right\}, SI={Education}subscript𝑆𝐼EducationS_{I}=\left\{\textsc{Education}\right\}, and SI,r​e​l={Employment}subscript𝑆𝐼𝑟𝑒𝑙EmploymentS_{I,rel}=\left\{\textsc{Employment}\right\}, we have queries of the form:
